Award.AwardTitle: Erbium Doped III-Nitrides for Optical Communications and Silicon Photonics

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is jointly funded by the Electronics, Photonics, and Magnetic Devices Program (EPMD) in the Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems (ECCS) and the Electronic and Photonic Materials Program (EPM) in the Division of Materials Research (DMR).

Intellectual Merit:
The project includes optimization of Erbium incorporation for enhanced optical efficiency; development of device fabrication processes of nitride optical amplifiers and emitters active at 1.5 microns; and new applications in optoelectronic technologies. The planned research will involve training of graduate and undergraduate students in the areas of novel materials growth, characterization, nano-fabrication techniques and material/device processing using the state-of-the-art facilities. The Er-doped III-nitride photonic structures may lead to novel electrically pumped optical amplifiers. Such devices would possess the unique advantages of semiconductor optical amplifiers (small size, electrical pumping, and ability for photonic integration) as well as those of Er-doped fiber amplifiers (minimal crosstalk between different wavelength channels in optical networks). The studies would also provide input for the development of suitable quality materials and the fundamental understanding of material properties, as well as the technological advancement in the fabrication of integrated optoelectronic devices active from infrared to deep UV.

Broader Impact: This proposal has the potential to make transformative advancements in development of electrically pumped, semiconductor optical amplifiers for optical communications and information processing. The project will involve training of graduate and undergraduate students in the areas of novel materials growth, characterization, nano-fabrication techniques and material/device processing using the state-of-the-art facilities. In addition, the PIs will continue their close relationship with local middle - high schools students and to recruit women into their research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Erbium (Er) doped materials have attracted much attention due to their applications in photonics, especially in the area of optical communications.  Doped in a solid host, Er ions possess an intra 4f shell transition from its first excited state (4I13/2) to the ground state (4I15/2), which matches perfectly with a wavelength of minimum optical loss in optic fibers (1.5 µm). Today, Er-doped fiber amplifiers (EDFAs) are an established technology in long-haul fiber communications. Unfortunately, with a typical size of tens of meters and requiring the use of an external pumping laser, Er-doped fiber amplifiers are difficult to integrate with many other functional photonic devices in the chip scale. On the other hand, traditional III-V semiconductor optical amplifier (SOA) is electrically pumped and integratable, but the crosstalk between different wavelength channels is a major problem for practical applications in optical communication network systems. The nonlinear crosstalk of SOAs is caused by the short carrier lifetimes of sub-nanosecond to nanosecond, which is intrinsic to free carrier recombination processes in semiconductors. This project is devoted to the incorporation of Er into GaN wide bandgap semiconductor, which ultimately will lead to emitters, optical amplifiers, and photonic integrated circuits (PICs) with functionalities that are not possible to attain from either Er optic fibers or traditional III-V semiconductor.

 During the supporting period, we have carried out epitaxial growth of Er doped GaN on various substrates and templates. We have developed a pulsed precursor flow MOCVD epitaxial growth method for the synthesis of Er doped GaN epilayers with alternating supplies of reaction precursors. Using this growth method, we have achieved GaN:Er epilayers with significantly improved crystalline quality. Our results also suggest that in order to improve the quantum efficiency of Er optical centers, the formation of the isolated Er optical center is preferred over the defect-related Er optical center.  Effective methods to produce Er doped GaN materials with enhanced 1.54 μm emission have been explored. Er doped GaN/AlN multiple quantum wells have been synthesized by MOCVD.  It was found that the emission intensity from MQWs:Er is 9 times higher than that of GaN:Er epilayers with a comparable Er active layer thickness. The results revealed that Er doped GaN/AlN MQWs consisting of well width between 1 and 1.5 nm and the largest possible barrier width before reaching the critical thickness provide the largest boost in QE of the 1.54 µm emission. These results demonstrate that MQWs provides a basis for efficient photonic devices active at 1.54 mm.

 The unique properties of Er doped GaN open up opportunities to fabricate novel electrically pumped optical amplifiers that possess the advantages of both semiconductor amplifiers (small size, electrical pumping, ability for photonic integration) and Er-doped fiber amplifiers (minimal crosstalk between different wavelength channels in WDM optical networks).  It would lead to integration with other functional optical devices, such as wavelength routers, optical switches, light sources, and detectors. The project has trained graduate students in the areas of novel material growth, characterization, nano-fabrication techniques and material/device processing using the state-of-the-art facilities. Opportunities have been provided to junior researchers to attend national conferences and workshops.
